knowledge about embedded development or the other internet of things or iot uh therefore i wanted to start with a really brief 101 level description of
what embedded development even is so embedded programming is this concept of writing code for incredibly small
computers aka microcontrollers those microcontrollers generally communicate with something like a
component like a sensor this one for example can measure temperature humidity and pressure
maybe they power servo motors that in turn can power can control other machinery
so we're building these really small programs that run on highly constrained devices and i say highly constrained in terms of
like the processing power and the available memory and that kind of stuff so these programs that we're writing are
generally doing one or more of the following things they're sensing something they're measuring something maybe they're
tracking something or controlling something so something physical right and in the embedded space you'll hear
this term firmware kind of bandied about um all you need to know about what firmware is it's essentially like
semi-permanent software loaded into non-volatile memory on a microcontroller right on a device you know it's not
software it's not hardware it's firmware so my journey from the web to the iot
without c sharp it involves some serious tool belt changes and change can be scary especially for
me so i go from writing c sharp and some javascript to writing arduino c maybe python
my ide changed obviously i moved away from visual studio into arduino ide or if i was lucky maybe
vs code with some helpful extensions or two and really fundamentally moving away
from working with the browser working with those really mature and engaging dev tools that have been you know
been fantastic over the last 10 15 years or so and moving into you know monitoring output from a serial
port and dealing with physical things like cheap sensors that break
wires that corrode combination of conflicts in some communication bus like
or power issues i mean it's just crazy the the expansion of how difficult things can get

right it includes internet connected flip-flops it's a belt that has an internet connection uh to your mobile device you

firmware updates that disrupt our workflow that happen in the middle of the day instead of at night they end up
adding friction to our lives instead of removing it it's new privacy concerns it's new security issues it's you know this
example of like a security device that can't tell a human face from a face printed on a t-shirt
so all of these make the iot super easy to dismiss as a fad which is a big problem
if you're familiar with gartner's hype cycle this is why they peg iot down here in the trough of disillusionment
but i would say there is hope the ios iot in general is still very much in its early stages and it's a very natural
next step as we advance from mainframes to pcs to mobility uh and beyond right devices are doing what they're getting
smaller and there's a lot more of them so as mobility is maturing right we're
entering into this wearable ar vr metaverse stage which definitely includes the iot

75 billion devices 15 trillion dollars as the analysts like to say
and i have three nice examples of real world problems that are being solved by the iot today these happen to be three
companies that we work with um i'm just putting them here not to tout us but just to provide like real practical
examples so american crane and equipment they're using the iot and our products to remotely monitor and diagnose issues
without technologists having to travel pretty obvious use case another one is with remote monitoring on
a different scale this has to do with greenhouses in colombia monitoring flowers they're gathering way more data
than they ever could have previously by using the iot and they're putting all this data into really friendly cloud dashboards right to really simplify that
process for them the third is within the healthcare industry another possible game changer for the iot industry there's a small
company we're working with in the caribbean who is actually building these devices and enabling
enabling these underserved populations to take devices home and communicate over cellular
where they have no broadband they have an internet access at home so there's this bi-directional healthcare possibilities with the iot as
well so i showed you those three examples to kind of demonstrate that the iot
really will succeed when it solves real problems in the embedded space right these problems where connectivity is
critical i like to say that you know connectivity is the secret sauce here and iot solutions that really focus
on solving these real problems with connectivity are the key to legitimizing the industry

what do they both offer well they are both completely free frameworks for using.net of course to

community editions as well and of course being a part of visual studio you get all the great features of

rosy picture here right all good things so far the downside is that both of them
offer only a small subset of the.net based class libraries this should not be a huge surprise really to anybody
because you can't really imagine you know downloading and installing the entire.net framework on a device with
maybe one or two megs of flash to spare so drilling in a little bit more to the
dot-net nano framework nano framework does provide fairly broad support for a variety of really popular
microcontrollers this is a big bonus it is fully open source it's mit licensed it is supported by the.net
foundation which i know the optics of that can be good or bad depending on previous projects you worked on that are
supported by them most intriguing from my perspective is they are working to align the nano
framework with the net core iot apis so these bindings that they call them can

likewise tiny clr stands out in its own ways what's interesting about them is they are more focused on tightly integrating

note hub notebook the blues wireless cloud service that receives data as a proxy from the note card this is because
the note card does not live on the public internet is a very secure device it does not have a public ip address so
it needs a proxy in the cloud to receive data however note hub will transparently route your
data to whatever cloud app you want to use you can transform that data on the fly do whatever you want you can just
have it immediately go to azure aws wherever you want to send it there's other features in node that aren't as
important today fleet management there's over the year firmware updates you can apply to your devices and note up again is all about

does utilize private vpn tunnels data can actually be encrypted like data
is literally sent off the internet off the public internet so to kind of help visualize where these
